												Really old first-person shooter with futuristic background, heavily based on the movie "Total Recall". Somehow, up to the moment, Chaser is the best game its creators, Cauldron, made for all those years.If you haven't played it before, when it was all fresh and comparable to the actual FPS on the market (2003, before such hits as Far Cry, HL2 and FEAR) - well, the game isn't aged well. If you're not down with old-school gaming mechanics, you'll most likely shouldn't try to play Chaser now. The game has many obvious and troublesome downsides, it is a real pain in the back for any casual nowadays gamer.However, if you happen to know the drill of the old-school shooters (where, for example, you need to hit crouch button in the middle of jump to reach higher altitude) - I suggest you to buy and play the game. It is a real deal challenge, especially on the hard difficulty. If you manage to beat it now, without all those modern features like flashing directional arrows, checkpoints and all-mighty recovering chest-high wall - well, welcome to the club, man!Let me tell you what was interesting in the game.First, it's the space. Not the out-world nothingness we call cosmos, no, I'm talking about really big levels. Almost every level here is huge, by every FPS standard. Sure, it's still a shooter on the rail, the most of the times there is only one possible route from start to end. But, that means kilometers of walking. Or driving. Or diving (there is an underwater level). Yeah, the most part of those wastes will be filled with primitive copy/paste textures - same trees, same buildings with the same posters, same decals inside buildings... But that practice is still all over the industry! And even brighter in that parade of uniformity looks some noticable cool things on the background, such as actual rotating of the space station in the intro chapter, with different stars and views of the Earth in the portholes. Or the funny snowman somewhere in the middle of taiga.All those big areas were made for the game to add some sense of realism. That kind of great achievement, when you to obtain some new thing have to actually do something, walk somewhere, elaborate, strive... and not just click two buttons on your phone to get all in your place - right away.Sure, not too many people would like to change the comfort of modern games which telling you what you should do, for something odd-looking and not providing you with the safe and quick routes.Second thing I liked in Chaser was the variety of missions. There is a sniping mission, where you need to protect a transport on its way through hostile military base. Exoskeleton mission, where you simply shoot your miniguns and rockets, defending the base. Stealth level, where you need to sneak around some goons to pick up some valuable conversation between some mobsters. Underwater level, where you swim... Swim, and then swim more, to get to some harbor "undetected". Well, on the way there are hundreds of aggressive droids which you need to shoot, and the route isn't too obvious even with markers, so maybe, that would not be the best entertainment in your life... But the whole game isn't! It's about to see of what you're made from. A challenge for your reaction time, coordination and patience. And your navigation skill.Finally, the story. Yeah, it's trivial for the most part, and its major pieces you'll recognize much faster than the game plot shows them to you. But, it's a long story, really comparable with the Half-Life by its length and number of events and changes in the pace and alignments. It's much better than modern "don't ask questions, just shoot'em all!" standards.Downsides are plenty, as I've warned you before.The levels are so huge, that the most amount of the game time you'll be wandering, where to move next. In theory, it's quite simple - just follow the blood trail, more precisely, go where there are enemies waiting. But, in every level, there are some switches to click, holes to jump in or crumbled ladders you're still gotta climb. Well, train your wits about it... or just watch it all on the youtube, like all weaklings do.The AI of your enemies... They aren't gonna find the cure from cancer, that's for sure. But their reaction time... Even if you catch someone off-guard and will try to shoot him in the nape, in a split second he'll be knowing where you are and shooting at you. If you ever played Counter Strike 1.6 (or earlier) with tough bots - that's them. Which is more - sometimes game spawns them on the cleared territory, behind your back. That's tough, unfair... but manageable, if you have your guts around.Finally, the proposed layout of the game keys is outrageous. Just change it right before the game start. You'll need your nightvision, 'cause it's usually night time around. You'll need a quick button for "reflextion mode" aka bullettime/slomo feature. Yeah, it's not that cool as in Max Payne or at least in FEAR - but it's still useful, especially on the hard difficulty level.Let's summarize again. The game is bad, by modern standards, it's not worth your time and money. It will hurt you badly.On the other side, if you're a tough son of a gun, who have many old shooter games as kindergarten toys... try this thing. For example, it's much more variable, than Die Hard Nakatomi Plaza. More realistic, in many ways. And when it's not - it's a challenge for you to overcome. So come - if you're ready. In my library, I'll give it not too high mark of 6.8/10. But I'll honor the Chaser and its developers, Cauldron people, for at least one decent and sincere game.

												Chaser is about as generic as an FPS can get. It even has a useless pseudo bullettime mode.You start off the game as John Chaser wakes up in some sort of cryogenic chamber on a space station with no idea who he is or why there is a small army destroying the space station in a rather over the top attempt to locate you.You are immediately thrown in the action as the mindless hordes of enemies start attacking you from all sides as you make your way off the space station, through streets and sewers and even through a rather peculiar mini-submarine segment. Despite not know who he is, and everybody else seemingly knowing, he never bothers to ask. He also lacks the capacity to say no even when warned repeatedly not to go into the service of a particular sociopath. All in all, this is one of those you can actually play twice without realizing it because it is all so generic and forgettable. Nothing stands out and nothing has been given that extra effort.

												Chaser is honestly one of the most innovative games of the past, present, and future generation. After playing over 100 hours of this game, it's obvious where the inspiration for Bungie's Halo: Combat Evolved came from. Sure, it came out two years after Halo, but that's because they only saw Jo Wood's amazing design. If the investors had given him his $17.26 before, Chaser could've revolutionized gameplay for PC and would've put the Xbox and PS2 out of business. My favorite part of the game is how the enemies just run into the wall in such a beautiful way. Sure, some might call it a glitch, but I know that was there by design. When Jo Wood presented the concept for Chaser to his two cats and a parrot (RIP Jo Wood the Parrot), he wasn't just imagining another game, he was imagining the future!By far the most interesting character is Thruster Man. (SPOILER ALERT) Thruster man is a deep and well thought out character that I know Jo Wood put hours into creation. His one goal is to appear for 30 seconds, shoot at you 3 times, then continue off into the sunset. You (John Chaser) must help him out by shooting him, otherwise he'll keep going, never to actually come back and do his one job, which is to kill you. The chemistry between him and John Chaser is one for the ages. I will be sure to tell my kids about Thruster Man when I grow up.Overall, I recommend this game, and look wish Jo Wood luck with his new developer team, Homeless Studios.

												I don't think I've found myself saying how bad a game is so often as while I was playing Chaser. Chaser is a run and gun FPS that is overly ambitious, and falls hard in just about every possible gaming aspect. I want to say it feels like a cross between Serious Sam and Red Faction, but to put this title in the same sentence as those other two is blasphemous.There are just so many bad things to rip on: The graphics are decent for a 2003 release although they could have probably toned down on the shiny, over-glossed textures. The shooter aspects are bearable and the story is kind of reasonable, albeit extremely disjointed and severely lacking any depth due to the main character's case of amnesia. Voice acting is respectable, although the character graphics make for a stiff delivery.If one thing stood out it's that Chaser is god awful too long. It took me over 15 hours to finish, but I'd say there's only 7-8 hours of real content here. All the excess fat is just mindless killing of never ending spawning AI in a maze of bland and boring visuals.The AI just sucks, period. They spawn above you, below you, behind you and you never really know where they are until you are taking damage. Toward the end of the game, the AI difficulty ramped up exponentially literally requiring me to quick save after each kill which reminds me, there's no auto save here so save early and save often. There has to be at least 1,000 grunts that are trying to kill you and there's not a whole lot of variety in the bad guys.The multitude of hidden passages and usable objects made it a chore just finding where you need to go next or what to do--no waypoints here. Some passages you even have to keep jumping until you get lucky enough to move on. But be careful because one wrong jump and you might end up getting your character stuck in that invisible crevice. Good thing you quick saved it just a moment ago right?Too many useless guns. Most of them lacked effective damage, especially the grenade attachments. Five grenades to kill one guy--really? Yet the enemy grenades are a one shot kill on me.I'm not even sure why I continued to press forward and complete it. I guess it was just a mind numbing case of hoping the next chapter would bring some clarity. In the end, I was left pretty much as clueless as when I first started.I'm going to go sulk in a corner for a while and reflect on the nonsense I just played. In the meantime may I recommend to you either Red Faction or Serious Sam instead of this garbage.

												Chaser is a first-person torture simulator.This game has a lot of weak spots, but the plot is not one of them. You play as John Chaser who is slow (and can't chase anyone unless he holds shift all the time). He lost memory and wants it back. Chaser travels the world to find it, visiting various locations. Random people help him in his quest (usually dying afterwards). Even though motivation of some characters is questionable, it is still hard to say that the story is bad.What's bad then? Everything else.Weapons have bad sounds and weak animations, can't feel the gun at all. It's like you shoot using plastic toys.Enemies are horrible in general. They have 2 modes: Bugged mode where enemy is stuck and can't shoot you (but still aware of you); Rage mode where enemy enters uncontrollable rage.First mode is fine, but second one sends shivers down my spine. Raged enemy can spot you even being hundreds of meters away. He can land shots while running backwards and capable of twisting his hands to shoot you without going out of hideout. Most of enemies are in raged mode and capable of 100-0 in like 2 seconds on normal difficulty (quicksaves are almost mandatory). Sound detection is horrible. Enemies can hear you walking and there is no chance to sneak upon them. Why does this game has a knife if there is not a single chance to use it? Enemies also like to spawn right behind you, right in front of you and they do that frequently.Game features HUGE levels with a lot of empty spaces and labyrinths. Prison level with red mist is one of the worst ones. Underwater level is vomit-inducing - what were devs thinking? Have they ever tried to play it more than once? Syberia level was a huge mess as well.Missions have a nice variety: sniping level, train level, sneaky level, run without weapons level, defend the base in exoskeleton level and underwater level. Others are just plain corridors where you run around looking for objectives and shooting enemies. Music is somewhat nice. Voiceover is so bad that it's amazing. Enemy battle screams are perfect (such as REEEEEEEEEEE and HOTSHOT). Protagonist sounds like he has Down's syndrome (which can be explained by the plot).Camera work and character animations are terrible, but that's what makes them golden. Chaser's face moves like in gmod poops, other npcs are suffering from cerebral palsy as well.This game is acceptable only in video form. Just watch it on youtube to save nerves and laugh during cutscenes.

 Starts off promising, betrays the first impression. The game starts off pretty alright, but the difficulty and mechanics are poorly designed. The game is built around a slow motion mechanic that slows down the game. It doesn't let you shoot faster or move faster, you still get hit like normal and bullets also travel like normal and the enemies just happen to be awfully accurate and have no problem downing you in just a few hits. That would be OK if your weapons were just as accurate and powerful, but they're usually underpowered after the initial parts of the game.I thought I'd like this game as some Rainbow Six type, but it doesn't pull off even that part well right after the starting sequence. The story is trying too hard to imitate a gritty American action movie from the period, either that or they didn't really care to put the effort into it - the voice acting is hardly if ever mediocre, the worst of which being our protagonist. Chaser sounds like he's not even taking his VO job seriously.  Speaking of which, the subtitles don't match the actual spoken lines  a majority of the time. And lastly, this game made me save scum. I don't ever save scum in a game, but the game doesn't even have checkpoints. It only saves after a new map loads, not during one. You die so quickly anyway that it's necessary.

												Been really undecided on what to think of this game, since it has some good aspects and some not so good. In general, it's not a bad FPS game. If you like single player FPS games, you might like it, but it's a very average shooter in every sense, and a lot of the time it may also feel rather unpolished, so I can't really recommend it.One thing that is commendable is that it has an actual story, something that FPS games normally lack, but the story is spaced out by overly long and repetitive linear levels, in many of which you only have a couple of weapons to use, and the same kind of enemy, so you keep ploughing through dozens of the same enemies in the same corridors. The progression through the levels also feels the same all the time. If you say come across 4 doors in the area, I bet you anything 3 will be locked and 1 is open for you to go through. And on a few occasions when every door is locked, means you just gotta find a good old vent.The game also never really autosaves during the levels and there are no checkpoints. So if you've forgotten to save for a while and die for some silly reason, like falling off a ladder, then you'll lose a lot of progress. My very first death was in the first level, getting crushed by the sliding double doors. I've no idea who would build the doors to actually do that, rather than, you know, sliding back open again if someone is passing through.The enemies always seem to be aware of your presence before you even know they're there. They'll spot you for miles and across the other end of a large map. Sure, it adds to the challenge, but it's also kinda cheap and annoying. If I am being shot at, I'd prefer to be able to see who is doing that without needing to squint my eyes.I had to leave the game on a sniping section, which is equivalent to an escort mission, except you're sitting in a lighthouse and have to cover your allies in a truck that's trying to make it through a military base with enemies shooting at it from everywhere. Not sure if I'd be willing to continue anymore.Not a bad game, but feels very rough around the edges and has a mediocre gameplay. I was only really liking the story. This game could've been better off as a first person RPG, akin to Deus Ex, in my opinion.

												Before we start i just want to say; Chaser is by no means as bad as people make it out to be.In fact, this is actually a GOOD game. Not SUPER good, not mediocore. No, it simply is GOOD.With that out of the way, we can begin.When i got this game, i went in, expecting a mediocore, if not ♥♥♥♥♥♥ experience. However, what i got was a lenghty, entertaining and mostly well executed game.For a game that was released in 2003, it both looks and plays very well. What is very obvious to me, is that Cauldron set out to make a visually impressive and huge game, rather then a story driven game.What i mean by this, is that the game's dialouge is completely off, and so are many sound effects, aswell as plot points.But, the enviroments, the characters, serval other visual elements and the shear size of the game, are not only amazing for the time, but also make up for the cons. I also want to add, that the screenshots on the Steam page for this game, are mostly from the same level, and are very misrepresentive of the game's overall look and design.Personally, i love the setting and design of the game, now it does use alot of grey and brown nuances like so many games do.But the fact that the setting and level design is a combo of futuristic and present day architecture is making it all the more appealing. It also sets the tone for the game, humanity beat down by political and global crisis, rebels, savages and mafia scum all fighting for dominance, all helps to give the game a very distinct and depressing feeling.One thing that most absolutely be commented individually, is the amazing 'breakable' glass. The glass will not break in one single point, it will break where ever you shoot it. Try it yourself, find a big juicy window and shoot out the corners and watch as it breaks as you want it to. Effects of this quality have not been matched by many games since, and Chaser defintly needs commenting for this. It is amazingGameplay wise it's pretty solid, nothing too special or underwhelming here. It functions as any good FPS game should, you also have the ability to slow down time using "Adrenalin Mode" this especially becomes usefull at later stages, when you run into many enemies at once. In latter parts of the game, everything becomes far more fast phased, and i had a short moment of throw back to the days of Doom. The cutscenes are a real joy, as they have some truely funny dialouge, and often awkward yet funny situations. The main protagonist's look at the world is truely funny, and makes me believe he is not right upstairs... That making him even more awesome then he already is.Alot of people probably want to know "Does the game have many bugs? Is it unplayable thanks to them?" the answer is; No.The game does not have any bugs, that hasn't been disregarded completey in other "cheerished" titles. The only annoyance, and this is not a bug, is the fact that you do not recieve any kind of 'response' when you take enviromental damage, or fall from a ladder. This can often cause you to die, while you thought you were beefed up on health. But it is a small thing, and incidents with it, are far and few between.Overall, this is a good game, and defintly one i had alot of fun playing. The game is insanely long, and this is done very well, as it manages not to drop in quality the further you get. (Though some levels are abit repeatitive.) The game also holds a nice challenge to it, even on the easiest difficulty, it can still be very hard.It is essentially worth every penny, of the 5€ it costs. And if you are looking for an old shooter, that has aged well, Chaser is one to go for. (with that price, you got no excuse)Thanks for reading, i hope this review has hooked you on getting this game. I am really saddened by the amount of hate that is thrown towards it, as it hardly deserves half of it.I hope you will enjoy it as much as i have.

												I'll start this review of by informing people that there is a slo-mo like ability mapped to the caps lock key by default. As far as I know (unless I skipped it somehow) the game doesn't actually inform you of this and I only found out by pure chance when I spazzed on my keyboard trying to get away from an explosion...so yeah there's that.Anywho as far as the game itself goes although I'm giving it a recomendation it is a real mixed bag game design wise. This is probably a game you'll have a love/hate relationship with. Overall the gunplay is great. I really enjoyed the old school twitch based no iron sights shooting and good old fashioned health and armour drops. It's the level design that really starts to let this game down in the last few hours. The first level has you going through a space station with very linier corridors with very little room for deviation whereas the next few levels open up a little more. About halfway through the game the levels start becoming a little too open, with unessessary doors and corridors becoming accessible and some just plain huge open spaces with zero guidence or indication where to go next. This is bearable though and it's not until the last few hours that it just gets tedious. The game starts resorting to horrible half-life like platforming (crouch jump and all) and extremely obscure and hidden paths like barely visible vents and holes in the ground. The end mission is definitelly the lowest point of the game unfortunately. There's also a terrible stealth mission very early in the game but thankfully it's the only one and is over reletively quickly.If you're looking for a game with a cohesive story I would look elsewhere as well. The plot is all over the place and the cutscenes and voice acting are laughable. It's a shame because the game takes you to some amazingly different locations like a space station, gang infested city slums, Russian bases crawling with soldiers and even eventually to Mars for the 'big' conclusion. The amazing variety of weapons is fantastic and they all handle differently making each of them very situational. So in conclusion, if you're looking for an old fashioned shooter with some fun gunplay I would say pick this up. Even if you don't play it all the way through to the boring conclusion (honestly the story ain't worth it) it's still a lot of fun.

												One of the best FPS ever.That's the short review, but here's the rest.This is definitely the best game from Cauldron, a small developer that was able to make their own, amazing, engine (kinda like few other small ones, like Croteam). It's weird because many of the other games developed by them ranges from "meh" to "uninstall right away", and most are just average.That's why this one comes by surprise when you play it: it looks awesome, it's huge, has the old-school feeling that, even in those years, was getting lost, and has that something that makes you keep playing until you reach its end.It's not perfect by any means, and it shows its age in many aspects, but once you get used to its bugs and the quick-save key, you'll be fully immersed in this fun, and very hard, classic FPS experience.The main problem about this game is the enemies, that are able to see you and "snipe" you with any weapon they are carrying from any place they are hiding in. You always have to be on the lookout for them, and always have a cover spot to quickly use in case of an encounter (which, in most cases, is a multiple encounter). That isn't making the game impossible, but you gotta have a very good aim, even at normal difficulty, to take them down before they do the same to you (headshots highly recommended). You also need to save often, and I really mean it.The good thing is that this game uses healthpacks and armor bonuses, so you can just not collect them until needed, like we all old gamers used to do back then.It's easy to ragequit this game, because some enemies are simply unforgiving, or because you died and forgot to save close to there, but you'll come back to it until you finally complete it if you like old-school shooters. The graphics still are enjoyable to this day, in my opinion, because of the nice quality of the textures and models, the amount of the special effects (including the spectacular glass breaking) and the sci-fi setup. Good music and proper sound effects, though the voice acting is the usual B-movie kind.Last but not least, there's some variety in the levels. Not only in their looks, that are very different from level to level, which keeps the experience fresh, but also because of some different from the usual objectives, like sniping enemies from a tower, or diving underwater. This game has basically them all, just like in AAA titles.I have no idea if multiplayer still works or is populated. When I played this game ages ago it was basically dead already, but it felt fun when I actually could find someone online, with some different modes than just DM/TDM.I think that if you're a FPS lover, this must be in your library. I already had it from back then but I purchased it again on Steam while on sale just because it's worth keeping it around, forever.

												When I was younger I remember having the demo-version of this game, which featured the Little-Tokyo and the following underground level and playing it over and over again. Maybe that's the reason I like this game so much.Anyways - Chaser is a true old school first person shooter. Long levels in which you might even get lost in your first playthrough but even though it's a shooter you will have lots of different experiences in this game.  Some examples - you flee from a space station, fight your way through mafia goons, defend a truck from incoming enemies and even have a long underwater level in which you have to fend off sentry u-boats while navigating through boat wrecks. There's also a very big range of your weapon arsenal that changes throughout the game. And, even though its from 2004, the graphics are still pretty good (if you turn your resolution up enough).Aside from shooting itself you have a Adrenaline-slow motion function that you can use against your enemies.Another important aspect of the game is the story about the Protagonist John Chaser and his amnesia, which is carried on by cutscenes and dialogues throughout the game. I give this game 9/10 because it was one of the first real shooters I owned and I'm never getting tired of the plain but awesome shooting mechanics in this game.

												Chaser, a classic FPS from 2003.The CloakNT engine remains one of my favorites, as I love its scalability, looks, feel, and editing tools. Cauldron pulled off some interesting effects in the engine like dynamically lit particle effects, tesselated water surface that reacts to gunfire impacts, hybrid static/dynamic lighting and shadowing, realistic glass/wood breakables engine, environmental effects (environment impacts scope ring [fog, ice, dirt, etc], emissives from bullet impacts (shoot pipes or pressured glass windows), etc. A lot of these things are absent entirely from modern games/engines. It is a sad testament to the negative impact of console gaming.The engine also is capable of rendering very large areas with long viewsheds with minimal performance cost. They did some really awesome things behind the scenes in the CloakNT engine, which is made even more impressive by the fact that the engine was created in-house from the ground up. Combat is pure oldschool and twitchy; good stuff.Music is superb, visual style is great (if inconsistent), and levels sprawl! They're huge, if sometimes a bit lacking in interactivity.I love the variety of environments you find in this game, as well as the various play mechanics you'll use along the way. Story is a cliche made of tropes and other cliches, but it works to good effect.Main voice actor sounds like John Wayne. What isn't to like?Multiplayer is fun and quick, a nice mix of Q3A and CS IF you can find a low-ping server. Lag compensation is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at best and anything above about 100ms you'll start to have lots of wtf moments.There are a few cheaters unfortunately, but a good game can be had most of the time.Do yourself a favor and get it for the massive singleplayer alone (20+hours)

												Well, I'll say one thing for Chaser: You definitely get a LOT of game for your money, especially considering that I got it on sale for a little over a dollar. This game is perhaps the longest FPS I've ever played. I finally completed it on medium difficulty after 36 hours of gameplay, (I know it says above that I put 47 hours into it, but I started a new game with 11 hours already clocked in). In addition to being long, this game is also extremely difficult. In fact, you will find yourself quick saving and quick loading A LOT; over and over again to get thorugh many areas and still maintain enough health and armor to advance further into the game. I don't think it's how the developers meant for the game to be played, but it's what needs to be done in order to complete it.Chaser is a very well done  futuristic, sci-fi FPS with a bullet time mechanic that tells a very interesting story through well written cut scenes, has a good musical score, (particularly on the Siberian levels) and will take the player from a space station, to various points on the globe, and finally to Mars. Ammo and enemies are plentiful, and there is a terrific variety in both weapons and level enemies, from space soldiers, mobsters, ghetto trash and punks, to Japanese buisness men. All are out to kill you. There is one level fairly early in the game called "Kabir" that is in my opinion the worst mission in the game. You have to defend a truck from waves of enemies but they keep coming and coming relentlessly, and it is so difficult, that I actually quit the game and didn't pick it up to try again until several years later. Aside from that level, the game is pretty fun. I recommend this game. As I understand it, it has quite a cult following, probably thanks to Inside Gaming's unfair treatment of it, (that youtube channel ripped apart some very brilliant games in my opinion - especially "Legendary"). But I will tell you that by far, the biggest flaw in this game is that there are WAY TOO MANY times in the game where you have absolutely no idea what to do. Ya, it's one of those games. Even after you've killed all the enemies in a level or a certain part of a level, you will almost always be wandering around forever trying to find that one tiny switch, or that one elusive ladder or hole in the corner that is too easy to miss, to advance into the next area. A few times there are level puzzels such as a board blocking a door that you have to shoot from a distance, so that you can open that door later in the level, but if you happen to not see that board, you will be wandering around forever trying to figure out what you're supposed to do. Every level of the game is basically like this and it gets old really quick. You will be scratching your head until you finally figure out what to do, or have to resort to a youtube playthrough. Also, I should note that the game has a very interesting twist at the very end with a completely unexpected ending. It's a challenging game that is best completed if, for nothing else, bragging rights. Anyway, I hope you enjoy it.

												What a truly terrible game, good grief. I started writing down things I found wrong with the game after stage one and I filled over half a page in no time flat. I'm tempted to just list them rather than write a proper review.First things first, what few "plot" points there are are ripped directly from Total Recall. In this game you take control of Douglas Quaid John Chaser as he proceeds to get his ??? to Mars. The first part immediately after you land is kind of neat and has decent cutscenes, but once you actually start to head towards Mars everything just turns into a mess and nothing makes sense at all. Prior to landing all the cutscenes are heavy flashing lights and shaking camera, and after they're just boring until the end.But people don't play FPS for the plot right? So the devs clearly focused on the gameplay! Right? Right?! Hahahahahahahahahahahahahah. Bullet damage and health spacing is reminiscent of the original Far Cry game  (that is to say very high and very poor) without any stealth mechanics or decent graphics. Further the AI is dumb as bricks and appears to be only able to open doors as part of scripted events. If a door shuts in front of them expecting them to be staring you in the face later. 99% of your damage taken will be from some enemy you never saw aimbotting you from above/below/behind/spawning out of thin air. There is absolutely no enemy variety, just guys with guns. And oftentimes it's only one gun per stage. One particularly badly designed stage only has one model for said enemy too (the rest of the stage is a tiny little area copy pasted about 8 or 9 times). The hit effect seems to be bugged or just not implemented right as well so oftentimes you don't even know if you're hit from things, especially falling or explosions.Did I mention doors? There are a LOT of doors. A lot. And the ones you can use and the ones you don't look EXACTLY the same. But you have to guess which one is right. I cannot emphasize enough how tedious this gets. There is a general lack of direction in the game that will have you wandering around aimlessly; everything looks the same in most of the normal levels. And some of the dead ends REALLY are dead ends; you can't get back. And the levels that attempt to mix it up... well... One of them is generic sniping mission where the graphics are mysteriously downgraded to N64 tier. You get to protect a truck with non-moving wheels as it glides along a port. There's a 'stealth' mission where you instantly die if you fail. But the worst offender is an underwater one with 6 degrees of freedom and seriously screwed up controls. I swear I spent 10-15 minutes where to go on one part of it.Unsurprisingly there are tons of bugs too. I:Got stuck on geometrySaw enemies spawning on top of each otherCrashed several timesFell through the level attempting to do a required jump to progressAbsolutely disgusting/10This game is not worth it even for a dollar.

In this game, they are literally five minutes long, often being slow and burning as much time as they can get away with. In one cutscene, the character was warned against a danger that got him in the very same cutscene.But enough about stupid cutscene/gameplay ratios, lets talk about the gameplay! Fairly early in the game, I met one of those stupid mandatory stealth sections where an enemy seeing one square inch of you results in an instant game over. The irritation there is enhanced by the game's complete lack of stealth mechanics. Not to mention that this section opened a plot hole; if the character is so valuable to his new owners, why are they so quick to murder him?"What about the combat?" What about the combat! It's boring and irritating. It feels like you are playing counterstrike against an army of murderous bots, but with less strategy and worse gun mechanics. You die quickly, which would be fine if enemies didn't regularly spawn behind you. This game basically demands that you save scum through it.All in all, Chaser promises a mediocre experience, but delivers far less than that.

												While I think I got my 1€ worth out of this game, Chaser can simply not be recommended. The shooting and the movement have the right feel to it. The music has the right ring to it. You even have a decent plot line with lots of skippable cutscenes. The maps are huge and range from cities and skyscrapers to space stations. Even the graphics are good enough for a game from it´s era. Sadly these things are not enough as Chaser has some *serious* flaws.When a map starts, you don't have any enemies anywhere. Instead they get spawned each time you hit a preset location. At best this can mean enemies spawning to a room you just cleared a few seconds ago. Naturally these spawns make no sounds so you will simply have an enemy taking a free shot at you from behind. Very annoying. The other major annoyance relates to the huge maps. Sometimes you have no clue where you are supposed to go or what on earth you are supposed to do. At least 1/4 of my gameplay time was simply running around checking which door can be opened in order to go forward. The best indicator of being on the right track is that enemies are still spawning around you. Otherwise you need to start guessing. To make this worse, it is possible to get stuck in some maps after which you are forced to restart the map. You can also get stuck in a lot of textures. Mostly this is just a minor annoyance cured by hitting your jump key a few times. Sometimes this means going for your last save. If you have no quick saves, this means restarting the map.Chaser claims to have "Highly developed AI". In practice this means that AI always knows your exact position aiming at you in advance. Enemies don't always run straight to you though so I guess we need to give some credit for that. Instead they try to do some sort of flanking manouvers. The enemy also knows when you reload and will atempt to attack you during these moments. In other words you can sometimes draw enemies from cover by simply reloading your weapon. The AI always aims at your torso even when it is behind a cover. This made some fights quite hilarious. Another hilarious thing relates to scoped weapons. They make more damage with the same bullets when you have your scope on. Very logical.To wrap it up, Chaser has some enjoyable moments but they are wrecked by aimless searching and enemies spawning from thin air. Add a few crashes with no autosaves and you will be feeling great for actually paying to play this game. Good thing it only cost me a few dota items. I'd give it a 6 ½ / 10.

												This game feels like it was a bunch of lost potential. In fact, I had some fun with this one, and I figure with a little more polish it could have been remembered as a classic. However, there are two really big problems that prevent me from reccomending (or finishing) this... two problems that suck the life out of what could otherwise have been a decent shooter. 1) Bad Level Desgin: In this game, YOU WILL BACKTRACK A LOT. For every path forward there are twenty dead ends... and most offer no reward whatsoever for exploration. In a linear, story-driven game, this is an extreme indictment! Huge chunks of gameplay waste the players time and only bring boredom and frustration.But there are also little problems to level desgin as well... things you would not normally think about until they go wrong. I will use an example from this game: There is this level with a HUGE arena where a battle takes place. That is fine and well. But after the battle I ended up spending nearly 15 minutes searching for the way forward. There was this pile of rubble you are suppsed to climb up  and then a ladder above that. However, THE LADDER'S TEXTURE BLENDED INTO THE WALL TEXTURE. I ended up climbing that rubble no less than four times trying to get out of the arena and it was only on the fourth that I saw, just barely, that damned ladder. Linear story-driven games, especially, cannot afford this kind of BS.2) General Shooting Brokenness:The second major problem involves a lot of minor issues with the shooting itself, but which add up to make a mediocure shooter downright frustrating. I will simply list them out:-Enemies often point towards you and are ready to shoot at you before they have line of sight. Not only does this not make sense, but it also give them an unfair advatage.-Enemies, thier weapons, AND THE PLAYER can clip through walls and doors, leading to many a BS damage (and the occational getting stuck).-When one enemy knows of you... all do (think about the point at the top and see what problems that causes).-Lack of varety. Enemies almost always consist of the same type (man with machine gun) with minor variations (now man has sniper).-Samey corridor shooting. Rather than challenge the player with novel situations and varied, complementary ememies... 90% of gameplay is walking down a corridor and shooting the samey enemies. -The game seems to depend on random health and armour pickups from enemies to sustain the player. Given how rapidly 100 health can go to 27 (which in most cases is as little as two shots from death) this turns certain portions of the game into peekaboo nightmares. -Finally, there are rare enemies (man with genade launcher) which can one-hit-KO you. This is OK in shooters provided there is enough warning and enough chance to dodge. In Chaser... you get no such chance and have to simply eat a couple of deaths. Fix the p i s s-poor level degisn and tweak the shooting? And you have something fun I would argue. But alas, Chaser has these problems, and I cannot reccomend it.

												Chaser is a horribly buggy semi-competent budget shooter. There are only two good things about it; the guns and the music. The story and voice acting are so bad it's painful, and good gunplay dosen't excuse many deaths that felt cheap. Additionally, I've become stuck in various objects that lay directly in my path, forcing me to reload from a past save. On multiple occasions I 've encountered horrible graphical glitches that made the game completely unplayable (see my screen shots for this game if your curious). Anything unrealted to shooting, such as a biref stealth section, is so poorly designed that I have to wonder why it's in the game at all.The gunplay itself is a lot of fun. There are several guns, and all behave more or less effectively. There is usually only 1 or 2 good weapons that you'll find yourself using throughout a level however, so there really isn't much point in the decent array you have to choose from.The terrible enemy AI is compensated for with a reduced ability for the player to take damage and a high level of accuracy on the part of the AI. Any single enemy can kill you if you arn't careful, and there are a lot of enemies, but the enemies themselves die so quickly that getting through a level without using the time-slowing feature is a completely viable option, provided you have good reflexes for whenever the enemies start popping out from behind corners. The time slowing feature itself is hugely dissappointing, as it recharges too slowly to be any fun.I've seen estimates of length that go up to 50 hrs of playtime and higher. I'm over half-way through the game at 5 hrs. Excluding deaths, I doubt this experience is longer than 8 hrs.Lots of people love this game, and while the shooting is good, the stealth section and an underwater section where I literally CAN'T SEE have me wondering why.

												"Mostly Positive." I'm going to assume most of these reviews are sarcastic. The game isn't garbage, but it's not even close to being good, nor would I recomend it to anyone.The graphics look horrible, even for 2003 standards. Devil May Cry 2, Tomb Raider: Angel of Darkness, Silent Hill 3, and Max Payne 2 all came out in 2003 and look amazing compared to Chaser. It's true that graphics aren't everything, but this game looks so much worse than it should. More than a couple of times, I've walked into rooms that don't even look like there are textures on the walls or floor.There was even an instance where I was watching a cut-scene where my partner was driving, and my character was sitting in the drivers seat just talking. My parnter was steering from the passegner's seat, only to have the characters switch places back and fourth two or three times during the cut-scene.I'm about 2 and a half hours through the game and I have NO idea what's going on. The story is jumping around like the developers/writers had a severe case of ADD. Characters are being introduced, only to have them die at the end of the cut-scene. In one instance. a commander was whispering to his boss while they were the only two people around, and his boss was speaking like the commander wasn't whispering. Also, the AI is pretty dumb.This game is just... really weird. And not in a good way; but the gameplay is at least on par with some shooters from 2003.I plan on finishing the game, so... maybe the story will come together by the end, but usually if a game doesn't seem at LEAST promising within the first couple of levels, I don't have much hope for it. Maybe the game will become a little more fun and cohesive, but I highly doubt that.As it sits, I'd give the game the benefit of the doubt and give it a 2/5.

Majestic. He doesn't know who he is, what he's doing here, why he is being sought by men in black uniforms and what they will do to him when they find him…The player's goal is to find out who Chaser really is and why he is being hunted.
